author: {'steamid': '76561198013792101', 'num_games_owned': 629, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1426897873}
review:
Three Fourths Home is an interactive short story of sorts. The main story, as far as I can see, has but one ending no matter which dialogue choices you make: the "interactivity" besides picking your words is holding down a button to drive...while you read. The graphics were simplistic and didn't work that well in terms of the main story. The epilogue was done quite a bit better: it had multiple endings - some bad that end it early, one "good" ending, all equally bleak - and the graphics actually fit the emotional tone of the narrative. Furthermore, at least the epilogue showed you the main character, as opposed to the main story where all you see is a car going along a background, and all the characters are merely heard, not seen. They're expressive enough but some facial expression would have been nice to go with it.

You'll notice I spent two and a half hours on this game. That was the main story once, the epilogue four times, going through the extras (including letting the soundtrack run all the way through for an achievement,) and then a final cutscene. So to do absolutely everything, less than three hours. Full disclosure: I did receive a free copy of this game from the developer. Do I think it was worth the time I invested? Only partly. Some of it was good, the rest I did not find a very engaging story - it IS a character study, do not assume plot of any kind. Will it be worth the time AND money that YOU invest in it? Sorry, in my opinion, no.

review:
This is part one of my launch-day play through.  (Part 2 is available on my same Youtube channel if you want to spoil it)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TCV9hrCu2G8

I have several complaints about this game.. 
(Be aware that reading this review does have minor spoilers)

First off, understand that even with the initial 10% discount, $7 USD is too much money for this kind of game.

Secondly, a big complaint is that I honestly think the choices you make likely matter not in the end as it seems that everyone is going to get the same or a very similar ending.

Third, I dont understand the point of needing to drive, of having controls for lights and a horn.  The lights and horn and zoom controls included offer absolutely ZERO SIGNIFICANCE in the game.

Fourth, Whats the point of needing to hold "D" down the entire story to drive?  Why not just make the car drive automatically and offer a pause option to the player if needed?  It's not like holding down the D button on your keyboard gives the game some great gameplay mechanics.  There is nothing to dodge, no reason to stop driving, slow down.  It's just making sure you hold down the D key to keep the story flowing along!  FOR AN HOUR!

Fifth, parts of the story make no sense at all.  Ben's story he tells his sister is "a cool story bro" but offers nothing to the main story's plot, makes no sense in the situation at all.  There's a massive rainstorm, tornadoes are risking the lives of everyone in the story, but Ben is going to tell her a 15 minute fantasy story he wrote about a mystical beast in a fantasy land?!?  Uhh, okay.

Sixth problem is that parts of the story also are awkward.  Options to have your star 24 year old female obsessing over the masturbation of her younger 16 year old brother while driving in a rain storm talking to her mother feels out of place, awkward, and 'forced'.. not natural.

Seventh problem.. Unsatisfying ending to say the least.  Why build up this much tension and require the player to read and hold down a D key for an hour for "that"?  WTF.  Garbage.

I like the writing, parts of it.  I like the theme of the game just fine.  But for $7, or over $6 at the current 10% off when I bought it... ehhh.  I just think it could have been done much, much better and for the price, we should probably get something besides this completely random, unsensical mess of a story.

If the game is 80% off, it might be a good value for the people who tend to like this kind of game, including myself.  Anything over an 80% off sale will likely leave you shaking your head and thinking exactly what I thought at the end.. "WTF".

Two thumbs down, as much as I want to like it, for all the reasons above and the fact that the negatives outweigh the postives.

review:
The game only took me about an hour to get through (epilogue included)...it could be that I'm a fast reader. The driving aspect of the game is not as complicated as it sounds...you simply hold in D to keep the story going.  You don't have to worry about dodging traffic or staying on the road.  Frankly it got annoying after a while.  While the story was indeed well done, I don't think that the game warrants a $7 price tag, especially since replayability is practically nil.  I'd give this a go if/when it drops in price, but it won't be for everyone.  I'm giving it a no-recommend based on the price and the content you get for said price.  Buy a Stephen King (or what have you) book that takes days to get through instead.
